case_name: Nagpur Electric Light Power Co. Ltd. v. Regional Director, Employees State Insurance Corporation

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 491 and 492 of 1965 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 491 and 492 of 1965. Appeals by special leave

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from the order dated September 17, 1963 of the Bombay High Court Nagpur Bench in Letters Patent Appeals Nos. 14 and 15 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: from the order-, dated September 17, 1963 of the Bombay High Court Nagpur Bench in Letters Patent Appeals Nos. 14 and 15 of 1963, V. Gupte, Solicitor-General and I. N. Shroff,

facts.text: The company and the employees filed two separate applications before the Employees Insurance Court under s. 75 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany and the employees filed two separate applications before the Employees Insurance Court under s. 75 of the Act for the determination of the question.

facts.text: Out of five categories of staff in appendices 1 to 5, those connected with receiving station and workshop (appendices 1 and 2) were employees, but those in engineering, stores, outdoor work, meter, consumers, allocation departments and administration (appendices 3,4,5) were not.

anchor.surface_text: Their case is that out of the five categories of staff mentioned in appendices 1 to 5 to the companypanys petition, those companynected with the receiving station and workshop  appendices 1 and 2  were employees

facts.text: Regional Director contested the applications but admitted that workers in items 5-14 of appendix 4 and items 1,7,8 of appendix 5 were not employees.

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Director, Employees State Insurance Corporation companytested the applications, but he admitted that the workers of the categories mentioned in items 5 to 14 of appendix 4 and items 1, 7 and 8 of appendix 5 were number employees

facts.text: Employees Insurance Court found that those workers and item 12 of appendix 5 were not employees.

anchor.surface_text: The Employees Insurance Court found that those workers and also the workers mentioned in item 12 of appendix 5 were number such employees. The companyrectness of this finding is number in issue

facts.text: Categories in dispute: Appendix III all, Appendix IV items 1-4, Appendix V items 2-6 and 9-11.

anchor.surface_text: The categories of workers mentioned in appendix 111, items 1-4 in appendix TV and items 2-6 and 9-11 of appendix V are as follows Appendix III Mains Senior  1  assistant engineers,  2  supervisors,  3  electricians,  4  overseers.

facts.text: Employees Insurance Court held the disputed workers were employees under s.2(9).

anchor.surface_text: The, Employees Insurance Court held that the aforesaid workers were employees within the meaning of S. 2  9  of the Act.

facts.text: Company and employees appealed to Bombay High Court Nagpur Bench under s.82; Abhayankar J. affirmed and dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany and the employees filed two separate appeals from this decision to the High Court of Bombay  Nagpur Bench  under S. 82 of the Act. Abhayankar, J. affirmed the finding

facts.text: Letters Patent appeals summarily dismissed by High Court Bench.

anchor.surface_text: Letters Patent appeals from his orders were summarily dismissed by a Bench of the High Court.

facts.text: Nagpur Electric Light Power Co. Ltd. occupies premises at Kamptee Road, Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: The Nagpur Electric Light Power Co., Ltd., occupies cer- tain premises at Kamptee Road, Nagpur where it carries on the work of transforming and transmitting electrical energy.

facts.text: Premises within compound wall; buildings include receiving station, workshop, meter testing department, engineers quarters, general office, stores.

anchor.surface_text: Me premises are located within a companypound wall. Inside the premises there are several buildings, yards and open spaces. The receiving station, the workshop, the meter testing department,

facts.text: Company does not generate electricity; receives in bulk from Maharashtra Electricity Board at Khaparkheda at 11,000 volts.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany does number generate electricity. It maintains a receiving station inside the premises where it receives electrical energy in bulk from the generating station of the Maharashtra Electricity Board at Khapparkheda.

facts.text: Energy stepped down from 11,000V to 3,300V or directly to 400V at substations, then distributed to consumers.

anchor.surface_text: The energy when received is of 11,000 volts. From the receiving station, the energy is either carried through electric supply lines to a transformer and is stepped down to 3,300 volts and is then carried to the sub-stations

facts.text: More than twenty persons working on the premises.

anchor.surface_text: On the premises more than twenty persons were and are working.

facts.text: Court finds the premises constitute a factory under s.2(12) ESI Act.

anchor.surface_text: The premises therefore companystitute a factory within the meaning of s. 2 12  of the Employees State Insurance Act, 1948.

facts.text: Transforming and transmitting electrical energy are manufacturing processes under s.2(k) Factories Act.

anchor.surface_text: In view of s. 2  k   iii , the process of transforming electrical energy from a high to a low potential and the process of transmitting the energy through supply lines are both manufacturing processes.

facts.text: Remuneration of disputed workers does not exceed 400 rupees a month.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon case that these workers are employed on remuneration which in the aggregate does number exceed four hundred rupees a month.

facts.text: All disputed workers are employed in connection with the factory's work of transforming and transmitting power.

anchor.surface_text: the companyrts below companycurrently found and in our opinion, rightly, that all the workers of the disputed categories are persons employed for wages in or in companynection with work of the companypanys factory

facts.text: Appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeals are dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Sub-stations are not independent factories.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon case that the stations are number independent factories.

facts.text: Company's factory located inside Kamptee Road premises bounded by compound wall.

anchor.surface_text: The companypanys factory has a fixed site. It is located inside the Kamptee Road and its boundaries are fixed by the companypound wall of the premises

facts.text: No part of premises used for purposes unconnected with manufacturing process.

anchor.surface_text: No part of the premises is used for purposes unconnected with the manufacturing process

facts.text: Assistant engineers, supervisors, electricians, overseers engaged in erection and maintenance of supply lines.

anchor.surface_text: The assistant engineers, supervisors, electricians, and overseers are engaged in the erection and maintenance of the electricity supply lines companynected with transmission of power.

facts.text: Clerks in accounts, time-keeping, filing departments maintain records for all departments including receiving station and workshop.

anchor.surface_text: The clerks in the accounts, time-keeping and filing departments are employed to maintain accounts, attendance registers, muster rolls, pay-sheets, typing, filing and dispatching documents required in companynection with all the departments
s. 2 9  of the Employees State Insurance Act, 1948  34 of 1948 .

concepts.interpretation: Defines 'employee' as any person employed for wages in or in connection with the work of a factory or establishment to which the Act applies, including those directly employed by principal employer on work of, incidental, preliminary or connected with factory work, whether inside or outside.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 491 and 492 of 1965. Appeals by special leave from the order-, dated September 17, 1963 of the Bombay

issues.text: The question in issue in these appeals is whether certain employees of the Nagpur Electric Light Power Co. Ltd. are employees within the meaning of s. 2 9 of the Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 34 of 1948

anchor.surface_text: The question in issue in these appeals is whether certain employees of the Nagpur Electric Light Power Co. Ltd.,am employees within the meaning of s. 2 9  of the Employees State Insurance Act, 1948  34 of 1948 .

issues.text: The first question is whether the company maintains a factory and if so, where its factory is located

anchor.surface_text: The first question is whether the companypany maintains a factory and if so, where its factory is located.

issues.text: The next question is whether the members of the staff of the categories mentioned in appendix 111, items 1-4 in appendix TV and items 2-6 and 9-11 of appendix V to the companys petition are employees within the meaning of s. 2 9 of the Employees State Insurance Act

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the members of the staff of the categories mentioned in appendix 111, items 1-4 in appendix TV and items 2-6 and 9-11 of appendix V to the companypanys petition am employees within the meaning of s. 2  9  of the Employees State Insurance Act.

arguments.claim: Out of the five categories of staff in appendices 1 to 5, those connected with receiving station and workshop (appendices 1 and 2) were employees under s.2(9), but those in engineering, stores, outdoor work, meter, consumers, allocation departments and administration (appendices 3,4,5) were not.

anchor.surface_text: Their case is that out of the five categories of staff mentioned in appendices 1 to 5 to the companypanys petition, those companynected with the receiving station and workshop  appendices 1 and 2  were employees

arguments.claim: Workers in items 5-14 of appendix 4 and items 1,7,8 of appendix 5 were not employees under s.2(9).

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court affirms the concurrent findings of courts below.

arguments.claim: Company's premises constitute a factory under s.2(12) ESI Act as there are 20+ workers, manufacturing process (transforming/transmitting power) carried on with aid of power, fixed site within compound wall, no unconnected parts.

anchor.surface_text: The first question is whether the companypany maintains a factory and if so, where its factory is located. The Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 applies in the first instance to all factories other than seasonal factories s.1 4

arguments.claim: Transforming electrical energy from high to low potential and transmitting through supply lines are manufacturing processes under s.2(k)(iii) Factories Act.

anchor.surface_text: In view of s. 2  k   iii , the process of transforming electrical energy from a high to a low potential and the process of transmitting the energy through supply lines are both manufacturing processes.

arguments.claim: Manufacturing process carried on not only in workshop/receiving station but over whole area of transmission including sub-stations; thus every part is factory under ESI Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court said This manufacturing process is carried on by the Company number only in the building called the workshop or the receiving station but over the whole area over which the process of transmission is carried on including the sub- stations

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f a worker in the Factories Act. The object of the Factories Act is to secure the health, safety, welfare, proper working hours, leave and other benef

arguments.court_reasoning: Startling proposition; factory must occupy fixed site (Halsbury, Ardeshir Bhiwaniwala); company's factory fixed within compound wall.

arguments.claim: Factory must have fixed site; company's factory located inside Kamptee Road premises bounded by compound wall.

anchor.surface_text: The companypanys factory has a fixed site. It is located inside the Kamptee Road and its boundaries are fixed by the companypound wall of the premises

arguments.claim: No part of premises used for purposes unconnected with manufacturing process.

anchor.surface_text: No part of the premises is used for purposes unconnected with the manufacturing process

arguments.claim: ESI s.2(9) 'employee' definition wider than Factories Act s.2(l) 'worker'; extends to field workers outside factory.

anchor.surface_text: It is to be seen that the definition of an employee in the Employees State Insurance Act is wider than that of a worker in the Factories Act.

arguments.claim: All disputed workers (assistant engineers, supervisors, etc., clerks, meter staff, admin staff) employed in connection with factory's transforming/transmitting work, directly by company.

anchor.surface_text: the companyrts below companycurrently found and in our opinion, rightly, that all the workers of the disputed categories are persons employed for wages in or in companynection with work of the companypanys factory

arguments.claim: ESI Corp v Raman distinguishable: there separate admin office for sales/unconnected work; here single establishment, all connected to transforming/transmitting, no separate unconnected establishment.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the Employees State Insurance Corporation, Bombay v. Raman 1  is distinguishable. In that case a companypany had a factory and an administrative office.

arguments.claim: Sub-stations not independent factories, but attendants' work directly connected to main factory work.

anchor.surface_text: Some are employed in the sub-stations. It is companymon case that the stations are number independent factories. The sub-stations attendants attend to work which is directly companynected with the

holdings.text: The premises therefore constitute a factory within the meaning of s. 2 12 of the Employees State Insurance Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The premises therefore companystitute a factory within the meaning of s. 2 12  of the Employees State Insurance Act, 1948.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 20+ persons working; manufacturing process (transforming/transmitting electrical energy) carried on with aid of power in part of premises; fixed site within compound wall; no part used for unconnected purposes.

holdings.text: In view of s. 2 k iii, the process of transforming electrical energy from a high to a low potential and the process of transmitting the energy through supply lines are both manufacturing processes.

anchor.surface_text: In view of s. 2  k   iii , the process of transforming electrical energy from a high to a low potential and the process of transmitting the energy through supply lines are both manufacturing processes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual application of Factories Act s.2(k)(iii) definition of manufacturing process.

holdings.text: A factory must occupy a fixed site... The company's factory has a fixed site. It is located inside the Kamptee Road and its boundaries are fixed by the compound wall of the premises.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us a startling proposition that every inch of the wide area over which the transmission lines are spread is a factory within the meaning of s. 2 12 . A factory must occupy a fixed site, see Halsburys Laws of England, 3rd ed., Vol. 71 ,art. 15, p. 15. The companypanys factory has a fixed site. It is located inside the Kamptee Road and its boundaries are fixed by the companypound wall of the premises

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects High Court's view that entire transmission area including city sub-stations is factory; relies on Halsbury and Ardeshir precedent requiring fixed site bounded by compound wall.

holdings.text: No part of the premises is used for purposes unconnected with the manufacturing process.

anchor.surface_text: No part of the premises is used for purposes unconnected with the manufacturing process

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual determination supporting entire premises as factory under s.2(12).

holdings.text: The definition of an employee in the Employees State Insurance Act is wider than that of a worker in the Factories Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is to be seen that the definition of an employee in the Employees State Insurance Act is wider than that of a worker in the Factories Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual comparison of s.2(9) ESI and s.2(l) Factories Act; purposive to extend benefits to field workers outside factory.

holdings.text: The courts below concurrently found and in our opinion, rightly, that all the workers of the disputed categories are persons employed for wages in or in connection with work of the company's factory and are directly employed by the company on work of or incidental to or connected with the work of the factory.

anchor.surface_text: the companyrts below companycurrently found and in our opinion, rightly, that all the workers of the disputed categories are persons employed for wages in or in companynection with work of the companypanys factory

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms concurrent findings; applies s.2(9) to duties connected with transforming/transmitting; wider than Factories Act worker.

holdings.text: The members of the staff of the categories mentioned in appendix III, items 1-4 in appendix IV and items 2-6 and 9-11 of appendix V to the company's petition are employees within the meaning of s. 2 9 of the Employees State Insurance Act.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the members of the staff of the categories mentioned in appendix 111, items 1-4 in appendix TV and items 2-6 and 9-11 of appendix V to the companypanys petition am employees within the meaning of s. 2  9  of the Employees State Insurance Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detailed application to specific roles (engineers, clerks, etc.) all connected to factory work; remuneration <400 rs.

holdings.text: The case of the Employees State Insurance Corporation, Bombay v. Raman is distinguishable.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the Employees State Insurance Corporation, Bombay v. Raman 1  is distinguishable. In that case a companypany had a factory and an administrative office.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Here single establishment all connected to factory work; unlike Raman's separate sales office with unconnected functions.

holdings.text: The sub-stations attendants attend to work which is directly connected with the work of the factory at the main station. They are therefore employees within the meaning of s. 2 9 (i).

anchor.surface_text: Some are employed in the sub-stations. It is companymon case that the stations are number independent factories. The sub-stations attendants attend to work which is directly companynected with the

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-stations not independent factories (admitted); work directly connected.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals dismissed, confirming that the categories of workers mentioned in appendix III, items 1-4 in appendix IV and items 2-6 and 9-11 of appendix V are employees within the meaning of s. 2(9) of the Employees State Insurance Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us a startling proposition that every inch of the wide area over which the transmission lines are spread is a factory within the meaning of s. 2 12 . A factory must occupy a fixed site, see Halsburys Laws of England, 3rd ed., Vol. 71 ,art. 15, p. 15. The companypanys factory has a fixed site. It is located inside the Kamptee Road and its boundaries are fixed by the companypound wall of the premises
In the result the appeals are dismissed with costs.
